title: Old Key

nouns: Metal device shaped in such a way that when it is inserted into the appropriate lock the lock's mechanism can be rotated
Instrument that is used to operate a lock
Device designed to open and close a lock.
A key is a device that is used to operate a lock.
An object designed to be able to open (and usually close) a lock.
An object designed to open and close a lock.
A device used to open a lock or door
A prearranged reply to the challenge of a sentry.
An authentication credential similar to a password, consisting of numbers.
A secret word or phrase known only to a restricted group
A group element, expressed as a product of group elements.
A string of characters used to log in to a computer or network, to access a level in a video game, etc.
In military terminology, a countersign is a sign, word, or any other signal previously agreed upon and required to be exchanged between a sentry or guard and anybody approaching his or her post.
A password is a word or string of characters used for user authentication to prove identity or access approval to gain access to a resource, which should be kept secret from those not allowed access.
Used for user authentication to prove identity or access approval
A prearranged reply to the challenge of a sentry or a guard; a password or signal by which friends can be known from enemies
A sign used by a sentry or guard.
The response to a sign or signal.
In group theory, a word is any written product of group elements and their inverses.
A secret word.
A string of characters, known only to a user, used, along with a user name, to log in to some computer or network etc.
A product of group elements and their inverses
A string of characters used for authentication on a digital device.
A string of characters entered by a user to verify his or her identity to a network or to a local computer, device, or client, or to sign in to an account, app, and so on.

description:
An old-fashioned key, as opens an antique chest or wardrobe. Generally depicted at a 45° angle as a tarnished, silver skeleton key with an ornate, bowed head and two-toothed bit at the bottom left.

Like üîë Key, often used figuratively, e.g., the key to success, being key ("crucial"). May also be applied to antiques.

Microsoft’s design is gold, with the head at the upper left. Samsung and Facebook’s keys were previously gold.
apple_vendor_description: On Apple devices, the old key emoji is rendered with a charming, antique aesthetic, featuring a dark, burnished metal finish that hints at its age and history. Apple's characteristic 3D shading and realistic lighting accentuate the intricate details of the key's bit and the worn texture of its bow, giving it a substantial and authentic feel. This emoji symbolizes access, secrets, solutions, and the unlocking of opportunities, often appearing in contexts related to discovering something new or gaining entry.
